user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of irq:
```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function irq:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int irq_handler(int irq, void *priv)
{
	(void)irq;
	(void)priv;

	return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
		  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
explanation: Other controlling expressions in the function do not appear to be invariant and therefore do not require investigation under Rule 14.3: the for-loop controls (i = 0; i < 2; i++) depend on the loop variable i which is modified; conditions testing rc (if (rc)) and the combined (err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc) depend on runtime-updated variables (rc and err_msg) set by function calls and code flow; calls to eventfd, metal_irq_register/metal_irq_unregister and close have side effects that affect runtime values; the irq_handler shown only returns a value and has no controlling expression. Therefore these other fragments are not suspect for an invariant controlling-expression violation.
